subject: Re: JUnit 4.x and support for Java 1.4
msgSnippet: Cedric, Are you sure this is all Mark meant? I thought he was asserting a functional advantage ... not merely contrasting the stylistic nuances of the two API
messageBody:
Cedric,

Are you sure this is all Mark meant?

I thought he was asserting a functional advantage ... not merely
contrasting the stylistic nuances of the two API approaches
(inheritance vs. declarative).

(You wouldn't want a large organization to incur the expense of
retooling their localhost in-container test environment just for a
matter of style. Right?)

_Marvin (OOP bigot :-)


--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "CÃ©dric Beust â" " <cbeust@...> wrote:
>
> On 9/15/06, Marvin Toll <MarvinToll@...> wrote:
> >
>
> With annotations, you no longer need to extend TestCase.
>
> The reason: methods that used to have to be named a certain way in
order to
> be noticed by the testing framework (test*, setUp, tearDown) can
now be
> marked by annotations.
>
> --
> Cédric
> http://testng.org
